I weep for Adonais — he is dead!</br>O, weep for Adonais!  though our tears</br>Thaw not the frost which binds so dear a head!</br>And thou, sad Hour, selected from all years</br>To mourn our loss, rouse thy obscure compeers,</br>And teach them thine own sorrow, say:  with me</br>Died Adonais; till the Future dares</br>Forget the Past, his fate and fame shall be</br>An echo and a light unto eternity!

Where wert thou mighty Mother, when he lay,</br>When thy Son lay, pierced by the shaft which flies</br>In darkness?  where was lorn Urania</br>When Adonais died?  With veiled eyes,</br>'Mid listening Echoes, in her Paradise</br>She sate, while one, with soft enamoured breath,</br>Rekindled all the fading melodies,</br>With which, like flowers that mock the corse beneath,</br>He had adorned and hid the coming bulk of death.

O, weep for Adonais — he is dead!</br>Wake, melancholy Mother, wake and weep!</br>Yet wherefore?  Quench within their burning bed</br>Thy fiery tears, and let thy loud heart keep</br>Like his, a mute and uncomplaining sleep;</br>For he is gone, where all things wise and fair</br>Descend; — oh, dream not that the amorous Deep</br>Will yet restore him to the vital air;</br>Death feeds on his mute voice, and laughs at our despair.

Most musical of mourners, weep again!</br>Lament anew, Urania! — He died,</br>Who was the Sire of an immortal strain,</br>Blind, old, and lonely, when his country's pride,</br>The priest, the slave, and the liberticide,</br>Trampled and mocked with many a loathed rite</br>Of lust and blood; he went, unterrified,</br>Into the gulf of death; but his clear Sprite</br>Yet reigns o'er earth; the third among the sons of light.

Most musical of mourners, weep anew!</br>Not all to that bright station dared to climb;</br>And happier they their happiness who knew,</br>Whose tapers yet burn through that night of time</br>In which suns perished; others more sublime,</br>Struck by the envious wrath of man or God,</br>Have sunk, extinct in their refulgent prime;</br>And some yet live, treading the thorny road,</br>Which leads, through toil and hate, to Fame's serene abode.

But now, thy youngest, dearest one has perished,</br>The nursling of thy widowhood, who grew,</br>Like a pale flower by some sad maiden cherished,</br>And fed with true love tears, instead of dew;</br>Most musical of mourners, weep anew!</br>Thy extreme hope, the loveliest and the last,</br>The bloom, whose petals nipt before they blew</br>Died on the promise of the fruit, is waste;</br>The broken lily lies — the storm is overpast.

To that high Capital, where kingly Death</br>Keeps his pale court in beauty and decay,</br>He came; and bought, with price of purest breath,</br>A grave among the eternal. — Come away!</br>Haste, while the vault of blue Italian day</br>Is yet his fitting charnel-roof!  while still</br>He lies, as if in dewy sleep he lay;</br>Awake him not!  surely he takes his fill</br>Of deep and liquid rest, forgetful of all ill.

He will awake no more, oh, never more!—</br>Within the twilight chamber spreads apace,</br>The shadow of white Death, and at the door</br>Invisible Corruption waits to trace</br>His extreme way to her dim dwelling-place;</br>The eternal Hunger sits, but pity and awe</br>Soothe her pale rage, nor dares she to deface</br>So fair a prey, till darkness, and the law</br>Of mortal change, shall fill the grave which is her maw.

O, weep for Adonais! — The quick Dreams,</br>The passion-winged Ministers of thought,</br>Who were his flocks, whom near the living streams</br>Of his young spirit he fed, and whom he taught</br>The love which was its music, wander not,—</br>Wander no more, from kindling brain to brain,</br>But droop there, whence they sprung; and mourn their lot</br>Round the cold heart, where, after their sweet pain,</br>They ne'er will gather strength, or find a home again.

And one with trembling hands clasps his cold head,</br>And fans him with her moonlight wings, and cries;</br>"Our love, our hope, our sorrow, is not dead;</br>See, on the silken fringe of his faint eyes,</br>Like dew upon a sleeping flower, there lies</br>A tear some Dream has loosened from his brain."</br>Lost Angel of a ruined Paradise!</br>She knew not 'twas her own; as with no stain</br>She faded, like a cloud which had outwept its rain.

One from a lucid urn of starry dew</br>Washed his light limbs as if embalming them;</br>Another clipt her profuse locks, and threw</br>The wreath upon him, like an anadem,</br>Which frozen tears instead of pearls begem;</br>Another in her wilful grief would break</br>Her bow and winged reeds, as if to stem</br>A greater loss with one which was more weak;</br>And dull the barbed fire against his frozen cheek.

Another Splendour on his mouth alit,</br>That mouth, whence it was wont to draw the breath</br>Which gave it strength to pierce the guarded wit,</br>And pass into the panting heart beneath</br>With lightning and with music:  the damp death</br>Quenched its caress upon his icy lips;</br>And, as a dying meteor stains a wreath</br>Of moonlight vapour, which the cold night clips,</br>It flushed through his pale limbs, and past to its eclipse.

And others came . . . Desires and Adorations,</br>Winged Persuasions and veiled Destinies,</br>Splendours, and Glooms, and glimmering Incarnations</br>Of hopes and fears, and twilight Phantasies;</br>And Sorrow, with her family of Sighs,</br>And Pleasure, blind with tears, led by the gleam</br>Of her own dying smile instead of eyes,</br>Came in slow pomp; — the moving pomp might seem</br>Like pageantry of mist on an autumnal stream.

All he had loved, and moulded into thought,</br>From shape, and hue, and odour, and sweet sound,</br>Lamented Adonais.  Morning sought</br>Her eastern watchtower, and her hair unbound,</br>Wet with the tears which should adorn the ground,</br>Dimmed the aerial eyes that kindle day;</br>Afar the melancholy thunder moaned,</br>Pale Ocean in unquiet slumber lay,</br>And the wild winds flew round, sobbing in their dismay.

Lost Echo sits amid the voiceless mountains,</br>And feeds her grief with his remembered lay,</br>And will no more reply to winds or fountains,</br>Or amorous birds perched on the young green spray,</br>Or herdsman's horn, or bell at closing day;</br>Since she can mimic not his lips, more dear</br>Than those for whose disdain she pined away</br>Into a shadow of all sounds: — a drear</br>Murmur, between their songs, is all the woodmen hear.

Grief made the young Spring wild, and she threw down</br>Her kindling buds, as if she Autumn were,</br>Or they dead leaves; since her delight is flown</br>For whom should she have waked the sullen year?</br>To Phoebus was not Hyacinth so dear</br>Nor to himself Narcissus, as to both</br>Thou Adonais:  wan they stand and sere</br>Amid the faint companions of their youth,</br>With dew all turned to tears; odour, to sighing rush.

Thy spirit's sister, the lorn nightingale</br>Mourns not her mate with such melodious pain;</br>Not so the eagle, who like thee could scale</br>Heaven, and could nourish in the sun's domain</br>Her mighty youth with morning, doth complain,</br>Soaring and screaming round her empty nest,</br>As Albion wails for thee:  the curse of Cain</br>Light on his head who pierced thy innocent breast,</br>And scared the angel soul that was its earthly guest!

Ah woe is me!  Winter is come and gone,</br>But grief returns with the revolving year;</br>The airs and streams renew their joyous tone;</br>The ants, the bees, the swallows reappear;</br>Fresh leaves and flowers deck the dead Seasons' bier;</br>The amorous birds now pair in every brake,</br>And build their mossy homes in field and brere;</br>And the green lizard, and the golden snake,</br>Like unimprisoned flames, out of their trance awake.

Through wood and stream and field and hill and Ocean</br>A quickening life from the Earth's heart has burst</br>As it has ever done, with change and motion,</br>From the great morning of the world when first</br>God dawned on Chaos; in its stream immersed</br>The lamps of Heaven flash with a softer light;</br>All baser things pant with life's sacred thirst;</br>Diffuse themselves; and spend in love's delight,</br>The beauty and the joy of their renewed might.

The leprous corpse touched by this spirit tender</br>Exhales itself in flowers of gentle breath;</br>Like incarnations of the stars, when splendour</br>Is changed to fragrance, they illumine death</br>And mock the merry worm that wakes beneath;</br>Nought we know, dies.  Shall that alone which knows</br>Be as a sword consumed before the sheath</br>By sightless lightning? — th' intense atom glows</br>A moment, then is quenched in a most cold repose.

Alas!  that all we loved of him should be,</br>But for our grief, as if it had not been,</br>And grief itself be mortal!  Woe is me!</br>Whence are we, and why are we?  of what scene</br>The actors or spectators?  Great and mean</br>Meet massed in death, who lends what life must borrow.</br>As long as skies are blue, and fields are green,</br>Evening must usher night, night urge the morrow,</br>Month follow month with woe, and year wake year to sorrow.

He will awake no more, oh, never more!</br>"Wake thou," cried Misery, "childless Mother, rise</br>Out of thy sleep, and slake, in thy heart's core,</br>A wound more fierce than his with soars and sighs."</br>And all the Dreams that watched Urania's eyes,</br>And all the Echoes whom their sister's song</br>Had held in holy silence, cried:  "Arise!"</br>Swift as a Thought by the snake Memory stung,</br>Prom her ambrosial rest the fading Splendour sprung.

She rose like an autumnal Night, that springs</br>Out of the East, and follows wild and drear</br>The golden Day, which, on eternal wings,</br>Even as a ghost abandoning a bier,</br>Had left the Earth a corpse.  Sorrow and fear</br>So struck, so roused, so rapt Urania;</br>So saddened round her like an atmosphere</br>Of stormy mist; so swept her on her way</br>Even to the mournful place where Adonais lay.

Out of her secret Paradise she sped,</br>Through camps and cities rough with stone, and steel,</br>And human hearts, which to her aery tread</br>Yielding not, wounded the invisible</br>Palms of her tender feet where'er they fell:</br>And barbed tongues, and thoughts more sharp than they</br>Rent the soft Form they never could repel,</br>Whose sacred blood, like the young tears of May,</br>Paved with eternal flowers that undeserving way.

In the death chamber for a moment Death</br>Shamed by the presence of that living Might</br>Blushed to annihilation, and the breath</br>Revisited those lips, and life's pale light</br>Flashed through those limbs, so late her dear delight.</br>"Leave me not wild and drear and comfortless,</br>As silent lightning leaves the starless night!</br>Leave me not!"  cried Urania:  her distress</br>Roused Death:  Death rose and smiled, and met her vain caress.

"Stay yet awhile!  speak to me once again;</br>Kiss me, so long but as a kiss may live;</br>And in my heartless breast and burning brain</br>That word, that kiss shall all thoughts else survive</br>With food of saddest memory kept alive,</br>Now thou art dead, as if it were a part</br>Of thee, my Adonais!  I would give</br>All that I am to be as thou now art!</br>But I am chained to Time, and cannot thence depart!

"Oh gentle child, beautiful as thou wert,</br>Why didst thou leave the trodden paths of men</br>Too soon, and with weak hands though mighty heart</br>Dare the unpastured dragon in his den?</br>Defenceless as thou wert, oh where was then</br>Wisdom the mirrored shield, or scorn the spear?</br>Or hadst thou waited the full cycle, when</br>Thy spirit should have filled its crescent sphere,</br>The monsters of life's waste had fled from thee like deer.

"The herded wolves, bold only to pursue;</br>The obscene ravens, clamorous o'er the dead;</br>The vultures to the conqueror's banner true</br>Who feed where Desolation first has fed,</br>And whose wings rain contagion; — how they fled,</br>When like Apollo, from his golden bow,</br>The Pythian of the age one arrow sped</br>And smiled! — The spoilers tempt no second blow,</br>They fawn on the proud feet that spurn them lying low.

"The sun comes forth, and many reptiles spawn;</br>He sets, and each ephemeral insect then</br>Is gathered into death without a dawn,</br>And the immortal stars awake again;</br>So is it in the world of living men:</br>A godlike mind soars forth, in its delight</br>Making earth bare and veiling heaven, and when</br>It sinks, the swarms that dimmed or shared its light</br>Leave to its kindred lamps the spirit's awful night."

Thus ceased she:  and the mountain shepherds came,</br>Their garlands sere, their magic mantles rent;</br>The Pilgrim of Eternity, whose fame</br>Over his living head like Heaven is bent,</br>An early but enduring monument,</br>Came, veiling all the lightnings of his song</br>In sorrow; from her wilds Ierne sent</br>The sweetest lyrist of her saddest wrong,</br>And love taught grief to fall like music from his tongue.

Midst others of less note, came one frail Form,</br>A phantom among men; companionless</br>As the last cloud of an expiring storm</br>Whose thunder is its knell; he, as I guess,</br>Had gazed on Nature's naked loveliness,</br>Actaeon-like, and now he fled astray</br>With feeble steps o'er the world's wilderness,</br>And his own thoughts, along that rugged way,</br>Pursued, like raging hounds, their father and their prey.

A pardlike Spirit beautiful and swift—</br>A Love in desolation masked; — a Power</br>Girt round with weakness; — it can scarce uplift</br>The weight of the superincumbent hour;</br>It is a dying lamp, a falling shower,</br>A breaking billow; — even whilst we speak</br>Is it not broken?  On the withering flower</br>The killing sun smiles brightly:  on a cheek</br>The life can burn in blood, even while the heart may break.

His head was bound with pansies overblown,</br>And faded violets, white, and pied, and blue;</br>And a light spear topped with a cypress cone,</br>Round whose rude shaft dark ivy tresses grew</br>Yet dripping with the forest's noonday dew,</br>Vibrated, as the ever-beating heart</br>Shook the weak hand that grasped it; of that crew</br>He came the last, neglected and apart;</br>A herd-abandoned deer struck by the hunter's dart.

All stood aloof, and at his partial moan</br>Smiled through their tears; well knew that gentle band</br>Who in another's fate now wept his own;</br>As in the accents of an unknown land,</br>He sung new sorrow; sad Urania scanned</br>The Stranger's mien, and murmured:  "who art thou?"</br>He answered not, but with a sudden hand</br>Made bare his branded and ensanguined brow,</br>Which was like Cain's or Christ's — Oh!  that it should be so!

What softer voice is hushed over the dead?</br>Athwart what brow is that dark mantle thrown?</br>What form leans sadly o'er the white death-bed,</br>In mockery of monumental stone,</br>The heavy heart heaving without a moan?</br>If it be He, who, gentlest of the wise,</br>Taught, soothed, loved, honoured the departed one;</br>Let me not vex, with inharmonious sighs</br>The silence of that heart's accepted sacrifice.

Our Adonais has drunk poison — oh!</br>What deaf and viperous murderer could crown</br>Life's early cup with such a draught of woe?</br>The nameless worm would now itself disown.</br>It felt, yet could escape the magic tone</br>Whose prelude held all envy, hate, and wrong,</br>But what was howling in one breast alone,</br>Silent with expectation of the song,</br>Whose master's hand is cold, whose silver lyre unstrung.

Live thou, whose infamy is not thy fame!</br>Live!  fear no heavier chastisement from me,</br>Thou noteless blot on a remembered name!</br>But be thyself, and know thyself to be!</br>And ever at thy season be thou free</br>To spill the venom when thy fangs o'erflow:</br>Remorse and Self-contempt shall cling to thee;</br>Hot Shame shall burn upon thy secret brow,</br>And like a beaten hound tremble thou shalt — as now.

Nor let us weep that our delight is fled</br>Far from these carrion kites that scream below;</br>He wakes or sleeps with the enduring dead;</br>Thou canst not soar where he is sitting now.—</br>Dust to the dust!  but the pure spirit shall flow</br>Back to the burning fountain whence it came,</br>A portion of the Eternal, which must glow</br>through time and change, unquenchably the same,</br>Whilst thy cold embers choke the sordid hearth of shame.

Peace, peace!  he is not dead, he doth not sleep—</br>He hath awakened from the dream of life—</br>'Tis we, who lost in stormy visions, keep</br>With phantoms an unprofitable strife,</br>And in mad trance, strike with our spirit's knife</br>Invulnerable nothings. — We decay</br>Like corpses in a charnel; fear and grief</br>Convulse us and consume us day by day,</br>And cold hopes swarm like worms within our living clay.

He has outsoared the shadow of our night;</br>Envy and calumny and hate and pain,</br>And that unrest which men miscall delight,</br>Can touch him not and torture not again;</br>From the contagion of the world's slow stain</br>He is secure, and now can never mourn</br>A heart grown cold, a head grown grey in vain;</br>Nor, when the spirit's self has ceased to burn,</br>With sparkless ashes load an unlamented urn.

He lives, he wakes — 'tis Death is dead, not he;</br>Mourn not for Adonais. — Thou young Dawn</br>Turn all thy dew to splendour, for from thee</br>The spirit thou lamentest is not gone;</br>Ye caverns and ye forests, cease to moan!</br>Cease ye faint flowers and fountains, and thou Air</br>Which like a mourning veil thy scarf hadst thrown</br>O'er the abandoned Earth, now leave it bare</br>Even to the joyous stars which smile on it's despair!

He is made one with Nature:  there is heard</br>His voice in all her music, from the moan</br>Of thunder, to the song of night's sweet bird;</br>He is a presence to be felt and known</br>In darkness and in light, from herb and stone,</br>Spreading itself where'er that Power may move</br>Which has withdrawn his being to its own;</br>Which wields the world with never wearied love,</br>Sustains it from beneath, and kindles it above.

He is a portion of the loveliness</br>Which once he made more lovely:  he doth bear</br>His part, while the one Spirit's plastic stress</br>Sweeps through the dull dense world, compelling there,</br>All new successions to the forms they wear;</br>Torturing th' unwilling dross that checks it's flight</br>To it's own likeness, as each mass may bear;</br>And bursting in it's beauty and it's might</br>From trees and beasts and men into the Heaven's light.

The splendours of the firmament of time</br>May be eclipsed, but are extinguished not;</br>Like stars to their appointed height they climb</br>And death is a low mist which cannot blot</br>The brightness it may veil.  When lofty thought</br>Lifts a young heart above its mortal lair,</br>And love and life contend in it, for what</br>Shall be its earthly doom, the dead live there</br>And move like winds of light on dark and stormy air.

The inheritors of unfulfilled renown</br>Rose from their thrones, built beyond mortal thought,</br>Far in the Unapparent.  Chatterton</br>Rose pale, his solemn agony had not</br>Yet faded from him; Sidney, as he fought</br>And as he fell and as he lived and loved</br>Sublimely mild, a Spirit without spot,</br>Arose; and Lucan, by his death approved:</br>Oblivion as they rose shrank like a thing reproved.

And many more, whose names on Earth are dark</br>But whose transmitted effluence cannot die</br>So long as fire outlives the parent spark,</br>Rose, robed in dazzling immortality.</br>"Thou art become as one of us," they cry,</br>"It was for thee yon kingless sphere has long</br>Swung blind in unascended majesty,</br>Silent alone amid an Heaven of Song.</br>Assume thy winged throne, thou Vesper of our throng!"

Who mourns for Adonais?  oh come forth</br>Fond wretch!  and know thyself and him aright.</br>Clasp with thy panting soul the pendulous Earth;</br>As from a centre, dart thy spirit's light</br>Beyond all worlds, until its spacious might</br>Satiate the void circumference:  then shrink</br>Even to a point within our day and night;</br>And keep thy heart light lest it make thee sink</br>When hope has kindled hope, and lured thee to the brink.

Or go to Rome, which is the sepulchre</br>O, not of him, but of our joy:  'tis nought</br>That ages, empires, and religions there</br>Lie buried in the ravage they have wrought;</br>For such as he can lend, — they borrow not</br>Glory from those who made the world their prey;</br>And he is gathered to the kings of thought</br>Who waged contention with their time's decay,</br>And of the past are all that cannot pass away.

Go thou to Rome, — at once the Paradise,</br>The grave, the city, and the wilderness;</br>And where its wrecks like shattered mountains rise,</br>And flowering weeds, and fragrant copses dress</br>The bones of Desolation's nakedness</br>Pass, till the Spirit of the spot shall lead</br>Thy footsteps to a slope of green access</br>Where, like an infant's smile, over the dead,</br>A light of laughing flowers along the grass is spread.

And gray walls moulder round, on which dull Time</br>Feeds, like slow fire upon a hoary brand;</br>And one keen pyramid with wedge sublime,</br>Pavilioning the dust of him who planned</br>This refuge for his memory, doth stand</br>Like flame transformed to marble; and beneath,</br>A field is spread, on which a newer band</br>Have pitched in Heaven's smile their camp of death</br>Welcoming him we lose with scarce extinguished breath.

Here pause:  these graves are all too young as yet</br>To have outgrown the sorrow which consigned</br>Its charge to each; and if the seal is set,</br>Here, on one fountain of a mourning mind,</br>Break it not thou!  too surely shalt thou find</br>Thine own well full, if thou returnest home,</br>Of tears and gall.  From the world's bitter wind</br>Seek shelter in the shadow of the tomb.</br>What Adonais is, why fear we to become?

The One remains, the many change and pass;</br>Heaven's light forever shines, Earth's shadows fly;</br>Life, like a dome of many-coloured glass,</br>Stains the white radiance of Eternity,</br>Until Death tramples it to fragments. — Die,</br>If thou wouldst be with that which thou dost seek!</br>Follow where all is fled! — Rome's azure sky,</br>Flowers, ruins, statues, music, words, are weak</br>The glory they transfuse with fitting truth to speak.

Why linger, why turn back, why shrink, my Heart?</br>Thy hopes are gone before:  from all things here</br>They have departed; thou shouldst now depart!</br>A light is past from the revolving year,</br>And man, and woman; and what still is dear</br>Attracts to crush, repels to make thee wither.</br>The soft sky smiles, — the low wind whispers near;</br>'Tis Adonais calls!  oh, hasten thither,</br>No more let Life divide what Death can join together.

That Light whose smile kindles the Universe,</br>That Beauty in which all things work and move,</br>That Benediction which the eclipsing Curse</br>Of birth can quench not, that sustaining Love</br>Which through the web of being blindly wove</br>By man and beast and earth and air and sea,</br>Burns bright or dim, as each are mirrors of</br>The fire for which all thirst; now beams on me,</br>Consuming the last clouds of cold mortality.

The breath whose might I have invoked in song</br>Descends on me; my spirit's bark is driven,</br>Far from the shore, far from the trembling throng</br>Whose sails were never to the tempest given;</br>The massy earth and sphered skies are riven!</br>I am borne darkly, fearfully, afar;</br>Whilst burning through the inmost veil of Heaven,</br>The soul of Adonais, like a star,</br>Beacons from the abode where the Eternal are.</br>
